messageBody:
Hi Joel,

Thanks very much for your response,I'd definitely try to get hold of
these books asap. I guess, I've a lot of homework to do now :-)

Thank you all for your suggestions..

Sarat kumar.

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Joel Neely" <joel.neely@...> wrote:
>
> Hi, Sarat,
>
> I would highly recommend:
>
> - Working Effectively with Legacy Code
> by Michael Feathers
> - Refactoring: Improving the Design of Existing Code
> by Martin Fowler, Kent Beck, John Brant, William Opdyke, Don
Roberts
> - Refactoring to Patterns
> by Joshua Kerievsky
>
> In fact, I'd recommend ALL of them, but if you have to pace
yourself,
> I'd suggest them in the above order. All are excellent, but it
sounds
> as if the first one is closest to "hands-on" immediate application
to
> your need.
>
> Good luck!
> -jn-
>

> > > Hi all,
> > >
> > > I've been stuck with a problem, when i'm unit testing my code.
> > >
> > > My problem is that i've a really huge method,which calls
several small
> > > methods ( methods so small, they're just getters for member
> > > variables), If i have to unit test this method, i've to make
sure all
> > > the small methods that it subsequently invoke, work as they're
> > > expected. But all my member variables get initialized
seperately in a
> > > different method which is of no relation with the BIG method
I wanted
> > > to test in the first place.
> > >
> > > Can I test my method without worrying about the
initialization of my
> > > object's data, by mocking the results of all my getter
methods ?
> > >
> > > Ex:
> > >
> > > Class MyClass
> > > {
> > > private Object _member;
> > > public void initialize()
> > > {
> > > //huge initialization process, which initializes my member
> > > variables.
> > > _member = new Object();
> > > }
> > >
> > > public void myHugeMethod()
> > > {
> > > //.. my logic here.
> > > Object m = getMember();
> > > //... proceed with this value.
> > > }
> > >
> > > public Object getMember()
> > > {
> > > return this._member;
> > > }
> > > }
> > >
> > > Now, if I call 'myHugeMethod()' without calling 'initialize
()' method,
> > > it always return NULL.
> > >
> > > All i wanted to do is to test 'myHugeMethod()', by mocking
> > > 'getMember()' method and setting the result what i wanted.
> > >
> > > I tried using Jmock for creating mocks in my test case, but
it fails
> > > because the mock object only knows what exactly I wanted to
mock but
> > > nothing more than that. All my application logic is present in
> > > 'MyClass' object not in its mock.
> > >
> > > How can I achieve this using Jmock ?
> > >
> > > FYI, I tried with a direct approach by extending 'MyClass' and
> > > overriding the 'getMember()' method in it. But I still feel
there's a
> > > better way to do it.
> > >
> > > I'll be very thankful for any help in this regard..
> > >
> > > Thanks in advance,
> > > Sarat kumar.
